Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Size Matters - The regulation of allometry in insects
Award.AbstractNarration:
The relationship between body and organ size, called allometry, defines the shape of an animal. It is no exaggeration to say that the evolution of animal form is to a great extent the evolution of allometry. Despite this, almost nothing is known of the processes that regulate allometry, leaving a conspicuous gap in our knowledge of how animals develop and evolve.

The goal of this research is to uncover the developmental mechanisms that regulate allometry. The research will take a molecular genetic approach to identify the genes that regulate allometry and examine how these genes act during development to ensure that final organ size correctly matches final body size. The results address a fundamental, as yet unanswered, question: how is growth of individual organs coordinated with growth of the body as a whole?

The outcome of the research will identify the developmental mechanisms that regulate animal shape, which is an essential first step in understanding how animal shape evolves. The broader impact of this proposal is that it will support the development of a program aimed at expanding the research opportunities for undergraduates at Michigan State University, particularly those from groups underrepresented in science. Furthermore, it will benefit the wider academic community through the development of a web-based tool (Flypic.org) specifically designed to facilitate the teaching of Drosophila genetics to undergraduates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
All animal species have a characteristic body shape. This shape is traditionally described using the relationship between body size and organ size among adults in a population, formally called an allometry. It is not exaggeration to say that variation in allometry underlies much of the variation in shape that we see among different animal species. Nevertheless, we know very little about the developmental processes that regulate allometry, an important prelude to understanding how these mechanisms evolve to generate diversity in body shape. The goal of our research was to identify the developmental mechanisms that regulate allometry, using the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster as a model organism.

In Drosophila, most organs scale isometrically with body size; that is the relationship between organ size and body size is constant across a range of body sizes and body shape does not change. In contrast, the male genitals are hypoallometric to body size; that is genital size is more-or-less the same regardless of body sizes, such that larger males have proportionally smaller genitalia whilst smaller males have proportionally larger genitals. We discovered the reason that the male genitals have a different relationship with body size than other organs is because the genitals are able to maintain growth rate in conditions where other organs, and the body as a whole, grow slowly. Growth rate in all animals is strongly influences by the environment, in particular the amount of nutrition a growing animal receives. When nutrition is low, animals’ bodies grow more slowly, producing smaller adults. For most organs, low nutrition slows their growth rate too, and the result is a small adult with small, but proportional, organs. In contrast, the genitalia are able to maintain their growth rate even when nutrition is low and the rest of the body is small, generating small adults with proportionally large genitalia.

How do the genitals maintain growth in conditions of low nutrition? Animals are small when nutrition is low because they produce a protein called FOXO that reduces the rate of cell division. FOXO can be thought of as a brake on growth rate, which is applied when nutrition is low. The genitals, however, do not produce FOXO and so the brake on growth rate is never applied. The result is that they grow to more-or-less the same size regardless of nutrition – accounting for their hypoallometric relationship with body size. Excitingly, if we increase the amount of FOXO in the genitals, genital growth now becomes sensitive to changes in nutrition, and the genitals scale more isometrically to body size, just like most other organs in the body.

Our research was one of the first examples of a developmental mechanisms that controls allometry. Consequently, our findings start to answer a fundamental biological question: how are physiological and developmental systems integrated to coordinate growth of individual organs with growth of the body as a whole? These mechanisms are crucial to building a correctly proportioned adult, and changes in these mechanisms underlies changes in body proportion, both adaptive and maladaptive.

The funding of our research also expanded research opportunities for early career undergraduates at Michigan State University, through the establishment of PURL, the Program for Undergraduate Research in Life Sciences. The PURL program is a structured four-year research program aimed at first-year students from groups traditionally underrepresented in science.
